A questioning and critical press is a necessary, if sometimes disquieting, part of any free•society.
With this idea in mind, we have consistently challenged views
which we believe harmful to the Hopkinscommunity in the long run.
The most recent, and perhaps most noteworthy, question we haye
raised this year has been directed against the Student Council. The
Council as it has existed in recent years, with very few exceptions,
has not acted with the viability and power it organically possesses,
and thereby it has not contributed in leading Hopkins students to a
more involved position in the university community, a position that
students should naturally hold.
Last Monday's Student Council meeting, in which several NewsLetter representatives were present, was a revealing one. The Council's strongly worded resolution deploring the University's handling
of the Bradford Beauty Salon discrimination case proved that the
Council can -be effective and relevant when it wishes. Several proposals and ideas were brought before the Council, and several members
reacted sympathetically and positively to the ideas.
Nevertheless, the presence of some obstructionists, notably Student Council President Bruce Ledig, is still putting a severe cramp
on what the Council could possibly achieve. A more concerned and a
less tiepititious leadership would solve two great problems: 1) it
would result in the Council becoming more involved in important
student issues, thereby enabling the bulk of Hopkins apathetic
morass to involve itself more in the community; and 2) it would result in creating a Council less concerned with petty political playing.
Ledig as Council figurehead is fine, as long as he does not enter into
and thereby obstruct any major discussion of university problems, as
he did at Monday's meeting when he persisted in changing every
essential discussion to irrelevant bantes.
Once again, we ask Council members with a modicum of concern,
such as Jim Winship or Manuel Rodriguez, to take a stronger leadership against the heel-draggers. It is important that the Council stop
wasting time with irrelevancies - - its travel service, visa cards and
Goucher buse5 - - and devote more of its energies to important and
controversial issues. If the Student Council continues to wallow in
its feat of confronting the Administration (or anybody else) on crucial issues, and fails to create meaningful programs on behalf of its
constituents, then it has failed.

Professorial Apathy
There is no doubt that the Hopkins faculty is among the best in
the country. But, while we recognize that fact, it is clear that our
professors have failed us in a critical area of our intellectual endeavor. While a war rages in Asia, and our cities stand at the brink of
chaos, our faculty is mute.
The inertia in the faculty is a disease that necessarily imposes a
political somnambulence on the Homewood campus. For too long,
the student has been castigated for failing to take an interest in the
critical issues of our day. The Hopkins student cannot rightfully be
asked to get excitedabout intellectual issues which even his professor
seems to care nothing about. Whether he realizes it or not, the professor exercises a great deal of influence over the opinions of his
students.
In other universitites throughout the nation, at Wisconsin and Harvard for example, the faculty displays an active interest in affairs that
do not necessarily pertain to their disciplines. The teach-ins at Wisconsin create a healthy atmosphere of debate on the crucial issues of
American foreign policy. These teach-ins saw biologists debating engineers and historian taking issue with political scientists.
At Hopkins, the professor comes to the classroom with the sole
intention of dispensing wisdom in his particular area of concentration. Vague allusions to Vietnam are not rare, but forthright commentary is eschewed. The person who suffers the' most from this
evasion from controversial subjects is the student.
The professor is among a privileged minority. He has chosen his
field and it is fun. He reads, he plays with ideas, he keeps up with the
professional gossip, he teaches a few hours a week for a few months
a year, he comes and goes as he pleases, he writes if he likes to, he
enjoys considerable (and rising) status in society, he bathes in the
adulation of his students, and he is surrounded by keen minds and
interesting people.
Unfortunately, this type of life may obscure the acute issues of
today. The world of Keats or Lincoln may consume his interest but
is there nothing that one can say about a civil war in Southeast Asia?
The crucial question is whether or not the professor can ignore the
the problems of today and concentrate instead on yesterday or tomorrow. It is regrettable that this ,cannot and should not be done,
for the poetry of Keats is far more plesant than the invective of a
George Wallace. But the George Wallaces'must be confronted by
superior minds and this is the great resource of the professor.
Professors undoubtedly grapple with the problems of our contemporary world, but his thoughts should not be left in his Gilman
Hall office. He must project them to the classroom in the hope of igniting interest among his students, who are ready to listen, if the
faculty is willing to speak.

A curious paradox recently appeared in the pages of the New York Times.
On the front page, a story appeared entitled, "Detroit Industry Hiring In
Ghetto." The article told how the Ford
Motor Company had begun a campaign to recruit the hardcorc unemployed in the Negro ghetto of the city.
The reporter claimed that this program
was an outgrowth of the summer riots
in Detroit.
In juxtaposition, there was an article inside the paper that reported the
recent hearings of the House Un-American Activities Committee on the summer riots. A Baltimore psychologist
testified that the "acts of many rioters
themselves constitutes subversion" because they are directed at overturning,
governments or the institutions of society.
The obvious question posed by
these two articles is - did the riots accomplish anything? The answer is an
unqualified yes. The riots in Newark,
Detroit, and New Haven were tragic in
the sense that lives were lost, property
and hatreds inflammed. But, the long
range effects will eventually mitigate
these angry scars and quite j)- ossibly
save the Negro from continued despair.
The wave of criticism that emanated
from the White House, the Congress,
City Hall and the market place pictured
the violence of the Negro as an aberration of a peaceful, law-abiding society.
Unfortunately,just the opposite is true.
The tradition of violence has existed in
this country since its inception. We achieved independence through war and
conquered the West the same way. The
experiences of the frontiersmen imbedded in the American character an
acceptance of violence as a_ proper
means of gaining desired ends. We had
to resort to violence to preserve the
nation when sectional interests threatened its -very existence. These events.
of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries served to set the stage for the

the roaring twenties.
In the twenties, America literally
ran wild. The unparalled prosperity of
that decade gave birth to a streak of
violence that held America by her gilded throat and threatened to choke her
to death. Al Capone, Frank Nitti and
the Ma Barker gang terrorized Chicago
and other cities while the police looked
on helplessly. But no one really cared
since America was listing high, wide
and handsome - - - - into a depression. The Depression spawned two of

were not the same beautiful people

recent movie. Instead, the real Bonnie
and Clyde were coarse, despicable, and
homosexual - and America loved them.
Today, America still loves Bonnie

Vince Lombardi and Floyd Patterson.

Like Bond and Lombardi; they extol

Only, no one seems to agree with them.

A questioning and critical press is a necessary, if sometimes disquieting, part of any free•society.
With this idea in mind, we have consistently challenged views
which we believe harmful to the Hopkinscommunity in the long run.
The most recent, and perhaps most noteworthy, question we haye
raised this year has been directed against the Student Council. The
Council as it has existed in recent years, with very few exceptions,
has not acted with the viability and power it organically possesses,
and thereby it has not contributed in leading Hopkins students to a
more involved position in the university community, a position that
students should naturally hold.
Last Monday's Student Council meeting, in which several NewsLetter representatives were present, was a revealing one. The Council's strongly worded resolution deploring the University's handling
of the Bradford Beauty Salon discrimination case proved that the
Council can -be effective and relevant when it wishes. Several proposals and ideas were brought before the Council, and several members
reacted sympathetically and positively to the ideas.
Nevertheless, the presence of some obstructionists, notably Student Council President Bruce Ledig, is still putting a severe cramp
on what the Council could possibly achieve. A more concerned and a
less tiepititious leadership would solve two great problems: 1) it
would result in the Council becoming more involved in important
student issues, thereby enabling the bulk of Hopkins apathetic
morass to involve itself more in the community; and 2) it would result in creating a Council less concerned with petty political playing.
Ledig as Council figurehead is fine, as long as he does not enter into
and thereby obstruct any major discussion of university problems, as
he did at Monday's meeting when he persisted in changing every
essential discussion to irrelevant bantes.
Once again, we ask Council members with a modicum of concern,
such as Jim Winship or Manuel Rodriguez, to take a stronger leadership against the heel-draggers. It is important that the Council stop
wasting time with irrelevancies - - its travel service, visa cards and
Goucher buse5 - - and devote more of its energies to important and
controversial issues. If the Student Council continues to wallow in
its feat of confronting the Administration (or anybody else) on crucial issues, and fails to create meaningful programs on behalf of its
constituents, then it has failed.

Professorial Apathy
There is no doubt that the Hopkins faculty is among the best in
the country. But, while we recognize that fact, it is clear that our
professors have failed us in a critical area of our intellectual endeavor. While a war rages in Asia, and our cities stand at the brink of
chaos, our faculty is mute.
The inertia in the faculty is a disease that necessarily imposes a
political somnambulence on the Homewood campus. For too long,
the student has been castigated for failing to take an interest in the
critical issues of our day. The Hopkins student cannot rightfully be
asked to get excitedabout intellectual issues which even his professor
seems to care nothing about. Whether he realizes it or not, the professor exercises a great deal of influence over the opinions of his
students.
In other universitites throughout the nation, at Wisconsin and Harvard for example, the faculty displays an active interest in affairs that
do not necessarily pertain to their disciplines. The teach-ins at Wisconsin create a healthy atmosphere of debate on the crucial issues of
American foreign policy. These teach-ins saw biologists debating engineers and historian taking issue with political scientists.
At Hopkins, the professor comes to the classroom with the sole
intention of dispensing wisdom in his particular area of concentration. Vague allusions to Vietnam are not rare, but forthright commentary is eschewed. The person who suffers the' most from this
evasion from controversial subjects is the student.
The professor is among a privileged minority. He has chosen his
field and it is fun. He reads, he plays with ideas, he keeps up with the
professional gossip, he teaches a few hours a week for a few months
a year, he comes and goes as he pleases, he writes if he likes to, he
enjoys considerable (and rising) status in society, he bathes in the
adulation of his students, and he is surrounded by keen minds and
interesting people.
Unfortunately, this type of life may obscure the acute issues of
today. The world of Keats or Lincoln may consume his interest but
is there nothing that one can say about a civil war in Southeast Asia?
The crucial question is whether or not the professor can ignore the
the problems of today and concentrate instead on yesterday or tomorrow. It is regrettable that this ,cannot and should not be done,
for the poetry of Keats is far more plesant than the invective of a
George Wallace. But the George Wallaces'must be confronted by
superior minds and this is the great resource of the professor.
Professors undoubtedly grapple with the problems of our contemporary world, but his thoughts should not be left in his Gilman
Hall office. He must project them to the classroom in the hope of igniting interest among his students, who are ready to listen, if the
faculty is willing to speak.

A curious paradox recently appeared in the pages of the New York Times.
On the front page, a story appeared entitled, "Detroit Industry Hiring In
Ghetto." The article told how the Ford
Motor Company had begun a campaign to recruit the hardcorc unemployed in the Negro ghetto of the city.
The reporter claimed that this program
was an outgrowth of the summer riots
in Detroit.
In juxtaposition, there was an article inside the paper that reported the
recent hearings of the House Un-American Activities Committee on the summer riots. A Baltimore psychologist
testified that the "acts of many rioters
themselves constitutes subversion" because they are directed at overturning,
governments or the institutions of society.
The obvious question posed by
these two articles is - did the riots accomplish anything? The answer is an
unqualified yes. The riots in Newark,
Detroit, and New Haven were tragic in
the sense that lives were lost, property
and hatreds inflammed. But, the long
range effects will eventually mitigate
these angry scars and quite j)- ossibly
save the Negro from continued despair.
The wave of criticism that emanated
from the White House, the Congress,
City Hall and the market place pictured
the violence of the Negro as an aberration of a peaceful, law-abiding society.
Unfortunately,just the opposite is true.
The tradition of violence has existed in
this country since its inception. We achieved independence through war and
conquered the West the same way. The
experiences of the frontiersmen imbedded in the American character an
acceptance of violence as a_ proper
means of gaining desired ends. We had
to resort to violence to preserve the
nation when sectional interests threatened its -very existence. These events.
of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries served to set the stage for the

the roaring twenties.
In the twenties, America literally
ran wild. The unparalled prosperity of
that decade gave birth to a streak of
violence that held America by her gilded throat and threatened to choke her
to death. Al Capone, Frank Nitti and
the Ma Barker gang terrorized Chicago
and other cities while the police looked
on helplessly. But no one really cared
since America was listing high, wide
and handsome - - - - into a depression. The Depression spawned two of

recent movie. Instead, the real Bonnie

homosexual - and America loved them.
Today, America still loves Bonnie

Vince Lombardi and Floyd Patterson.
One wonders why America doesn't like
Rap Brown and Stokley Carmichael.
Like Bond and Lombardi; they extol
the virtues of our violent tradition.
Only, no one seems to agree with them.
Incendiary individuals such as Brown
and Carmichael are feared by Americans who don't want their cities burned

as long as they are not the victims of
its wrath. But most Americans fail to
see that the Negro in the ghetto is more
